oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Case report: Toxicosis in cattle caused by a discontinued organophosphorus insecticide (fonofos)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiedner, Ellen B.
Horstman, Lawrence A.
Hooser, Stephen B.
Levy, Michel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: case reports
clinical aspects
clinical examination
insecticides
medical treatment
organophosphorus insecticides
poisoning
steers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two crossbred cattle were presented to a veterinary teaching hospital in December 2001 with muscarinic, nicotinic and central nervous system signs consistent with severe organophosphorus (OP) insecticide toxicity. Despite treatment, neither animal survived. Over the course of 72 hours, 34 cattle died acutely. A subsequent veterinarian-led visit to the farm identified a rusted, leaking corn planter containing a gray crumbling material, situated near where the cattle were fed. This substance was later identified as fonofos, an agricultural insecticide and an OP that was voluntarily removed from the marketplace by the manufacturer in 1998.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Bovine Practitioner; Vol. 39, No. 1 (2005 February); 24-28
